bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert E. Truby, March 4, 1942

div1.p: Hench invites Truby to Rochester. Hench discusses the handwriting in the Lazear lab book, noting how much is attributed to Lazear and how much to Reed.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert E. Truby, March 4, 1942
div1.opener:
Y F.
March 4, 1942
General Albert E. Truby
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco, California
My dear General Truby:
div1.p:
Because of the war, my plans have been somewhat changed.
I am already losing my First Assistant to the army and because so many of our
Fellows are leaving, I am having a little trouble in getting new assistants.
The American College of Physicians has asked me to conduct a week's post-graduate
course for physicians from all over the country. This course on rheumatic diseases
will be given here in our department the second week in April, beginning the 13th
of April. On the 21st of April I am chairman of a round table conference at the
national meeting of the American College of Physicians in St. Paul. Thereafter
I will be free to start my vacation. I had hoped to come to California either
leaving here the last week in April (about the 24th) or the first week in May.
I am sorry indeed to hear that you may not be in California then. If so, I may
change my plans or not come at all. I had hoped, of vourse, to see Mrs. Lazear
but if you are not there I should be greatly disappointed. It is of course not
right for me to change any plans of yourself but as soon as you know whether you
will be in California the first week in May or the last week in April, I should
greatly appreciate hearing as this will revise my entire vacation plans.

Perchance you might be coming through Chicago. If you could
break your trip and spend a day there I should be almost tempted to come down and
meet you there, bringing a certain amount of material with me. Even better yet,
why not break it by stopping here for a couple of days? You really ought to see the
Mayo Clinic anyhow and I would knock off a couple of days from routine work in order
to be with you all the time, as host and guide. I believe you would find that there
are special rates here to take the extra trip through Rochester. You can come
straight here from Kansas City or Omaha and then go to Chicago on the Chicago North-
western. Since this is a medical center and so-called sanitarium, I believe it will
only cost you a very few dollars, perhaps less than five, to stop here. Will your
family be coming with you? If so, we should be delighted to have them also.

I sincerely hope that your manuscript will be published shortly.
Do you know where you are publishing it?

The writing in the New York Academy of Medicine notebook is
99 per cent identified. About 55 per cent is in the handwriting of Lazear (recognized
and identified by Mrs. Lazear), about 44 per cent is in Reed's handwriting (recognized
and identified by his children), only two or three pages remain unidentified. They may
indeed be Neate's.
div1.closer: Always sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
